content.raw:
Baila,

Quick fix attempt: `sudo apt-get install libgoogle-glog-dev` then recompile.  If this doesn’t work, let’s work through some of the steps below:

Were you ever able to get the SubT Repository setup and installed on your native OS as you attempted in issue #128?  Did the `catkin_make_isolated --install --use-ninja` command successfully complete?

Did you install all of the dependencies as listed on the [Native Installation Wiki page](https://bitbucket.org/jgrogers/subt_hello_world/wiki/Native%20Installation)?

Are you trying to build this on a system upgraded from 16.04 to 18.04?

content.raw:
Weird that this doesn’t work out of the box on a fresh 18.04 installation.  I’ll make sure to go through this later and update accordingly but for now how about trying this:

`sudo apt-get install ros-melodic-base-local-planner`

Then add a `CATKIN_IGNORE` file to the `tensorflow_object_detector` package if you do not plan to use it.  Otherwise please reference that compile issue to [this repository](https://github.com/osrf/tensorflow_object_detector).
content.html:
Weird that this doesn’t work out of the box on a fresh 18.04 installation. I’ll make sure to go through this later and update accordingly but for now how about trying this:

sudo apt-get install ros-melodic-base-local-planner

Then add a CATKIN_IGNORE file to the tensorflow_object_detector package if you do not plan to use it. Otherwise please reference that compile issue to this repository.

content.raw:
Does the following get rid of the DWA Local Planner error?

`sudo apt-get install ros-melodic-dwa-local-planner`

Like I said before, unless you're planning to use the `tensorflow_object_detector` package it’s best to just comment it out.

`touch ~/subt_hello_world/catkin_build_ws/src/tensorflow_object_detector/CATKIN_IGNORE`

Then:

`cd ~/subt_hello_world/catkin_build_ws; catkin clean -y; . ~/subt_hello_world/catkin_base_ws/install_isolated/setup.bash; catkin b`

Hopefully that successfully builds.
content.html:
Does the following get rid of the DWA Local Planner error?

sudo apt-get install ros-melodic-dwa-local-planner

Like I said before, unless you're planning to use the tensorflow_object_detector package it’s best to just comment it out.

touch ~/subt_hello_world/catkin_build_ws/src/tensorflow_object_detector/CATKIN_IGNORE

Then:

cd ~/subt_hello_world/catkin_build_ws; catkin clean -y; . ~/subt_hello_world/catkin_base_ws/install_isolated/setup.bash; catkin b

Hopefully that successfully builds.

content.raw:
Hi @{557058:14b7fd50-d65a-47a8-825c-fa89681d07bd} , thanks for your comment. That `ros-melodic-dwa-local-planner` installation solves the first error. Now I can see lots of green logs are coming \(e.g. 'found 6 frontiers' etc\) and got the `tensorflow_object_detector` package error little bit late \(but it is still coming\). But the X1 robot is now roaming around in the spawn area. I am not sure what is expected from it as per the tutorial.  
  
As you suggested to ignore the tensorflow package, if I do so, how objects would be detected and reported to the base station?
content.html:
Hi @Arthur Schang , thanks for your comment. That ros-melodic-dwa-local-planner installation solves the first error. Now I can see lots of green logs are coming (e.g. 'found 6 frontiers' etc) and got the tensorflow_object_detector package error little bit late (but it is still coming). But the X1 robot is now roaming around in the spawn area. I am not sure what is expected from it as per the tutorial.

As you suggested to ignore the tensorflow package, if I do so, how objects would be detected and reported to the base station?

content.raw:
If the robot is attempting to explore based upon frontiers, then that portion is working as intended.

As listed on the [subt\_hello\_world wiki](https://bitbucket.org/jgrogers/subt_hello_world/wiki/Home), there is another package \(Darknet\) included without a currently functional reporting node \(there is a legacy one present\).  I strongly recommend you do not pick the reporting algorithm solely based upon what is present and working as a baseline in subt\_hello\_world as writing the node to send detected object classifications to the base station is trivial compared to training and tuning your object detector and classifier.

Even if the Tensorflow Object Detector package did compile and run successfully for you, the current state of the subt\_hello\_world package is not enough load into any environment and successfully score a point.  The object detection/classification and reporting is currently the weakest part of the subt\_hello\_world repository and should be treated as such.  The current state of the subt\_hello\_world repository should be considered introductory as opposed to any sort of baseline to completing the SubT Virtual Challenge.
content.html:
If the robot is attempting to explore based upon frontiers, then that portion is working as intended.

As listed on the subt_hello_world wiki, there is another package (Darknet) included without a currently functional reporting node (there is a legacy one present). I strongly recommend you do not pick the reporting algorithm solely based upon what is present and working as a baseline in subt_hello_world as writing the node to send detected object classifications to the base station is trivial compared to training and tuning your object detector and classifier.

Even if the Tensorflow Object Detector package did compile and run successfully for you, the current state of the subt_hello_world package is not enough load into any environment and successfully score a point. The object detection/classification and reporting is currently the weakest part of the subt_hello_world repository and should be treated as such. The current state of the subt_hello_world repository should be considered introductory as opposed to any sort of baseline to completing the SubT Virtual Challenge.
